shortname: Consumption of fixed capital of corporations
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL] for methodological explanations.
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1999–2015: imputed value. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Compensation of employees paid from the rest of the world
simpledes: Compensation of employees paid to rest of the world is the total value of income accruing to employees as remuneration for their work.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

simpledes: Consumption of fixed capital of national economy is the decline in total value of fixed assets (e.g. roads, machines) which are owned and used by a producer. In other words, the amounts required to maintain the quality of fixed assets from a year to another. The decline in  value is a result of physical deterioration, normal obsolescence or normal accidental damage.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Gross domestic product is the total value of goods and services produced by the national economy.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

simpledes: National income aims to measure the total income available to the residents of a given country. It is equal to the gross domestic product (the total value of goods and services produced on the territory of a given country during a given year), minus fixed capital used in production processes (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads) plus the net foreign income earned by residents in the rest of the world.// National income has many limitations, however it is the only income concept that has an internationally agreed definition (established by the United Nations System of National Accounts, see SNA 2008). We thus use it as our reference concept (after corrections to include income hidden in tax havens). // The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [National income]=[Net domestic product]+[Net foreign income]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

shortname: Property income paid from the rest of the world
simpledes: Property income paid abroad is the total value of payments made by the national economy accruing to property owners as remuneration for using their property.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

shortname: Property income received from the rest of the world
simpledes: Property income received from abroad is the total value of income that the national economy receives by virtue of owning property.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL] for methodological explanations. method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2005–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1999–2004: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1970–1985: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Property income received from the rest of the world
simpledes: Property income received from abroad is the total value of income that the national economy receives by virtue of owning property.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Reinvested earnings on foreign portfolio investment, received from the rest of the world
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: After 1990, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017)[/URL_TEXT][/URL];[URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/2020-dina-update-for-countries-of-the-africa-region-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2020-03/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT] Updated by Robilliard, “Regional DINA update for Africa” (2020)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; Before 1990, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/countries-with-regional-imputations-on-wid-world-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2020-13/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel and Piketty, Technical Note: “Countries with Regional Imputations on WID.world” (2020)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1994, 1998, 2003, 2009, 2014. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Personal taxes on income and wealth
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL] for methodological explanations. simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: After 1990, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017)[/URL_TEXT][/URL];[URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/2020-dina-update-for-countries-of-the-africa-region-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2020-03/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT] Updated by Robilliard, “Regional DINA update for Africa” (2020)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; Before 1990, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/countries-with-regional-imputations-on-wid-world-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2020-13/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel and Piketty, Technical Note: “Countries with Regional Imputations on WID.world” (2020)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1994, 1998, 2003, 2009, 2014. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: The Gini coefficient is a measure of statistical dispersion. A coefficient of zero expresses perfect equality between individuals. A coefficient of one expresses maximal inequality, where only one person owns all the income or wealth of the economy.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: After 1990, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017)[/URL_TEXT][/URL];[URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/2020-dina-update-for-countries-of-the-africa-region-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2020-03/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT] Updated by Robilliard, “Regional DINA update for Africa” (2020)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; Before 1990, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/countries-with-regional-imputations-on-wid-world-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2020-13/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel and Piketty, Technical Note: “Countries with Regional Imputations on WID.world” (2020)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

simpledes: Current national income adjusted by CPI, divided by national income of the base year adjusted by CPI. It measures the changes in the purchasing power of national income.
longtype: Indices
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.worldbank.org/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]World Bank[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: We cumulate inflation rates from the following sources; 1960-2018: GDP deflator from the World Bank; 2019: CPI from the World Bank.

simpledes: Index that reflects the availability of surveys and tax data enabling the measurement of income and wealth inequality.
longtype: Indices
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/transparency/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Inequality Transparency Index Methodology[/URL_TEXT][/URL][URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/inequality-transparency-index-update-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2020-12/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]; Burq, François and Chancel, Lucas. Inequality transaprency index update (2020)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: The inequality transparency index is estimated by the World Inequality Lab based on the availability of income and wealth surveys and tax data in the country considered. See http://wid.world/transparency/ for more information .

simpledes: Consumption of fixed capital of national economy is the decline in total value of fixed assets (e.g. roads, machines) which are owned and used by a producer. In other words, the amounts required to maintain the quality of fixed assets from a year to another. The decline in  value is a result of physical deterioration, normal obsolescence or normal accidental damage.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

simpledes: Gross domestic product is the total value of goods and services produced by the national economy.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1999–2015: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Net domestic product is the total value of the goods and services produced in a country, minus the value of the fixed capital used up in production (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads).The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net domestic product]=[Gross domestic product]-[Consumption of fixed capital of national economy]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL] for methodological explanations.
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1950–2019: estimated from other components. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Net foreign income is the difference between the total value of a country's citizens and companies earned abroad, and the total value of foreign citizens and overseas companies earned in that country.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net foreign income]=[Property income received from abroad]-[Property income paid abroad]+[Compensation of employees received from abroad]-[Compensation of employees paid to rest of the world]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2019: extrapolated from last available year; 2005–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1999–2004: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1986–1998: extrapolated from last available year; 1972–1985: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1971: extrapolated from last available year; 1970: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: National income aims to measure the total income available to the residents of a given country. It is equal to the gross domestic product (the total value of goods and services produced on the territory of a given country during a given year), minus fixed capital used in production processes (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads) plus the net foreign income earned by residents in the rest of the world.// National income has many limitations, however it is the only income concept that has an internationally agreed definition (established by the United Nations System of National Accounts, see SNA 2008). We thus use it as our reference concept (after corrections to include income hidden in tax havens). // The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [National income]=[Net domestic product]+[Net foreign income]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1999–2015: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

technicaldes: [Gross savings of households]=[Gross secondary income of households]+[Private expenditures of households]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1999–2015: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

technicaldes: [Taxes on production and imports]=[Taxes on products]+[Other taxes on production]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1999–2014: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

longpop: The population looked at is comprised of male individuals only.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: After 1990, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017)[/URL_TEXT][/URL];[URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/2020-dina-update-for-countries-of-the-africa-region-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2020-03/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT] Updated by Robilliard, “Regional DINA update for Africa” (2020)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; Before 1990, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/countries-with-regional-imputations-on-wid-world-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2020-13/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel and Piketty, Technical Note: “Countries with Regional Imputations on WID.world” (2020)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1994, 1998, 2003, 2009, 2014. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.

shortname: PPP conversion factor, LCU per EUR
simpledes: PPP conversion factor of curent local currency to current PPP EUR.
longtype: Exchange rate series
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.worldbank.org/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]World Bank[/URL_TEXT][/URL];
method: We extrapolate the PPP from the latest ICP (2017) using the evolution of the price index relative to the reference country.
